Correction - recycled plastics CAN be used in food safe containers, and here's how.  About 20 years ago, I worked for a company that built the computer controls for plastic injection molding machines, and in that job, I got to know a bit about the machinery, materials and methods used.  One method used to produce food safe containers with recycled plastic was one where the container (a bottle for instance) was blow molded by the machine, and in a super secret process which I believe the company may hold a patent on, a thin layer of actual food safe plastic was  injected on the inside of the container.  As close as I got to the machinery, I never quite knew how they did it, but it took place directly after the bottle was blow molded and before it exited the machine.  What you end up with is a normal looking bottle, made out of about 99% recycled plastic, with a layer of food safe plastic coating the interior.

With your chemistry background, can you can explain why urethane is such a "junk" polymer? Put it in the sunlight, it degrades. That "powderyness" it displayed when it was not totally set, it will display later with time (if it doesn't "seek its creation" and degrade to the goo that it came from first). (Have you ever seen a substance both crumbly and gooey at the same time?) I have seen that "memory foam" and other shipping flexible foams used for protecting expensive optical equipment, degrade into a slimy goo that absolutely destroys optics. Before it does that, it exudes a smelly, sticky substance that seems to condense on everything in the package, which no known organic solvent can remove. Even before that, when you open a case lined with urethane foam, there is a Godawful smell like an old chemistry lab. Urethane paints (very heavy "rubbery" paints) also do the same thing, along with stick-on rubber feet that are supposed to "protect" surfaces. Are you familiar with the carbon-loaded urethane foam used to insert static sensitive integrated circuits leads into? After 20 years, the leads are corroded off, and the foam becomes a crumbly, gooey, mess. I suspect some of this may be due to the plasticizers incorporated to make it flexible. This is supposedly the source of the "new car smell".

"Toxic?" But my employer told me that TDI was safe when they had me working with it. And also that I couldn't wear a respirator because it didn't do anything. And then they gave me bullshit food-service gloves so it got on my skin too.

I really need to get that lawsuit off the ground.

Seriously folks, be careful with that stuff. I developed adult-onset asthma which at first was only triggered by isocyanates, but shortly after my state legalized recreational marijuana I learned that I'm sensitive to that too. Can't smoke (it might literally kill me) and I can't even be around it. I tried a particulate respirator, but that didn't work and I've ended up needing a half-face OV respirator just to take the bus. (This is weird. Normally allergens have to be macromolecular chemicals that are large enough to activate an antibody, which means you usually can't be allergic to a VOC. However there's a mechanism where a reactive small compound can attack or bind to a macromolecule and turn it into an allergen.

These reactive compounds are called "haptens." Urushiol is a good example - most people are familiar with poison ivy, but it's also the source of natural East Asian lacquer ("urushi" in Japanese). Urushiol polymerizes in the presence of heat and humidity, producing a strong and chemically stable natural thermoset. Polyisocyanates also polymerize in the presence of water - the product is polyurea - or copolymerize with alcohols to produce polyurethane. Polyurea is stretchy, sticky, and fairly reactive - it can even be made to re-form covalent bonds with itself after being cut. Polyurethane is harder (but springy and resilient rather than friable) and chemically stable, useful for foams, paints, and finishes.

So honestly, the best way to think of isocyanates in the lab or workshop is that they're somewhat like urushi lacquer - they don't cause much of an acute reaction but they can be extremely irritating in the long run - and you really don't want either skin or lung contact.

 I also carry a rescue inhaler and my life kinda sucks a little more than it used to. The resulting polymers are amazing but it's a shame isocyanates can be so dangerous to work with. Probably the worst was losing my career, which has cut my earnings by about 70%. Like I said, I need to get my lawsuit off the ground.

The ratio of -OH groups to -NCO group will affect the density of your foam. Mostly the % water will affect the foaming. In industry we don't add the water/catalyst to a prepolymer. It's the other way around, a resin is made with a defined -OH value and water/catalyst is added. Then when it is time to create the foam a diisocyante (usually PMDI) is added. However this a quick reaction (since it is an industrial product) and foam times can be from 30sec to 10 min depending on amount of catalyst. DEG, DPG, Castor oils, soybean oils, are all common in production of polyurethane foams. Your foam was very brittle because of the excess of -NCO. Also when molding, using a silicone spray to spray the mold first will make it much easier to demold.

Back around 2000 I help develop a way of recycling waste PET x-ray film into insulation foam. The transesterification catalyst I came up with was another very common waste material that ended up as a structural part of the final product. The PU foam was made with industrial grade MDI using the converted film as the sole polyol with no additional polyols like castor oil. The process has fallen into disuse now with the introduction of digital x-rays. As far as I know no one is using the process commercially with PET bottle waste.

For me as a polymer engineer, it really was a pleasure to watch this video. Great stuff!

The ricinoleic acid triglyceride ester in castor oil, having 3 hydroxyl groups, contributes to formation of crosslinks (unlike the PET derived diol, which would only make a linear thermoplastic polymer when reacted with the toluene diisocyanate). The foam thus prepared is a thermosetting polymer which is rigid and cannot be melted by heating. The long chain structure of the ricinoleic acid triglyceride ester in the castor oil probably also prevents the foam from being too brittle.  I think that's why castor oil is added. Of course, it being a renewable resource only helps. Polymer chemistry is fascinating af.

As far as polymers go, PET can be a bitch when it comes to mechanical recycling. PET requires a thorough, even meticulous cleaning and drying before even a thought of putting it into an extruder crosses someone's mind, because water at high temperatures and pressures can lead to hydrolysis of PET. And water will readily do so if the opportunity arises, biting unfortunate recycler right in the ass in the process.

Another important thing to mention about recycling any plastic mechanically, everytime you shred, remelt, regranulate and remold it, the polymer chains get shorter and mechanical, thermal and chemical properties worsen. Which is why for certain applications, even outside of the food and medical industry, recycled material is highly unrecommended or even forbidden, IE in any safety application, highly stressed industrial parts and others. Other plastics can technically be recycled but doing so is a health hazard, Polyoxymethylene and Polyvinylchloryde, even others experience no change in any way during recycling, due to their high mechanical and thermal resistance, IE PEEK and other high performance plastics. However consumer plastics, PE, PP, PS, PVC and maybe PET and PBT, are usually not recycled due to consumers not being aware of how to do so
